page.title: About Formative Assessment
page.contents:
Formative assessment requires that the student demonstrate skill or knowledge.  Such demonstration can often best be captured by a performance assessment, rather than by a selected response test, which asks students to choose a correct response from among several answers presented.  For example, the best way to assess a student’s oral language skill is to listen to them speak.  So, you might create a lesson that asks the student to make an oral presentation, and include a scoring guide – or rubric - for assessing the student’s speech to help you gauge their performance.  Click on the link below to view an example of a rubric:

Sample Oral Presentation Rubric (pdf format)

Better still, you might decide to include the student in helping you create the lesson and the rubric, so the student becomes an equal partner in what he or she will be tested on.   In other words, involving your students in self-assessment ensures that the student is invested in the process (a stakeholder), has a clear understanding of the goals to be achieved (because they helped to establish them), and has command of determining whether those goals have been met (they must decide if they have met their own expectations).

________________________________________________________________________

Click on the Next button below to continue.

page.title: Formative Assessment Activity
page.contents:
Video Activity – Formative Assessment

The video from New American Horizons linked below shows teachers conducting activities that demonstrate various forms of classroom assessment.  We ask you to select and view one section of the video Assessing Learning in the Adult ESL Classroom – we do NOT ask you to view the WHOLE 25 minute video.  While you watch your selected segment, make note of specific activities that strike you and be prepared to discuss your questions and thoughts with others.

Sections:

  • Times 2:40-5:30:  Aligning instructional goals, objectives and outcomes
  • Times 5:30-12:24:  Assessing in a variety of ways
  • Times 12:24-18:40:  Assessing using the task-based approach
  • Times 18:40-21:30:  Assessment as an on-going process
  • Times 21:30-23:38:  Providing feedback/student self-assessment

New American Horizons video Assessing Learning in the Adult ESL Classroom*

Assessing Learning in the Adult ESL Classroom

Questions for Discussion:

As you watch your selected video segment, make note of your responses to the following discussion prompts.

  • What questions do you have about the assessment activities in the video section you chose?
  • Can you provide more examples of how you use this form of assessment with your learners? (Or how you would like to use this form of assessment with your learners?)

________________________________________________________________________

* This video may also be viewed online here: http://bcove.me/dn3gtalv - note that there may be a delay in loading.

page.title: Resources for Optional/Further Study
page.contents:
Diagnostic and Formative Assessment – Classroom Assessment

The following resources provide research on, and examples of, practical application of various types of classroom assessment.  

  • Assessment FOR Learning Defined
    Rick Stiggins, 2005

  • Inside the Black Box:  Raising Standards Through Classroom Assessment
    Paul Black and Dylan Wiliam, King’s College London School of Education, November 1998
  • Assessment Matters:  Self Assessment and Peer Assessment
    Dorothy Spiller, February 2012
